title: 112_s965
content: The "Family Act of 2011" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings as well. The "Family Act of 2011" is also known as the Family Act. It highlights the recognition of infertility as a disease by the World Health Organization and the emerging public health priority it poses. Medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments is limited, with only 8 states requiring comprehensive coverage, leading to significant out-of-pocket expenses for treatments like in vitro fertilization. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR CERTAIN INFERTILITY TREATMENTS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section providing a credit for infertility treatments. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows eligible individuals a tax credit of 50% of qualified infertility treatment expenses, up to a limit of $13,360 per year. The credit is reduced for individuals with adjusted gross income over $150,000. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is reduced for individuals with adjusted gross income over $150,000. No credit is allowed if a deduction or credit is taken under another provision, or if reimbursement for the expense is received from a Federal, State, or local program. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is limited if reimbursement is received from a Federal, State, or local program, or under an insurance policy. The credit amount for a taxable year cannot exceed the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus other allowable credits. The credit allowed for infertility treatment expenses is limited by the regular tax liability and tax imposed by section 55, minus other allowable credits. Unused credits can be carried forward to the next taxable year. The credit for infertility treatment expenses can be carried forward to the next taxable year if it exceeds the limitation imposed for the current year. No credit can be carried forward beyond the 5th taxable year after it arose. Qualified infertility treatment expenses include amounts paid for such treatments. Qualified infertility treatment expenses refer to amounts paid for in vitro fertilization treatment administered by a licensed medical practitioner for infertility diagnosed by a US licensed physician. Expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical treatments that may cause infertility can also qualify. In advance of infertility arising from medical treatments, expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before procedures that may cause involuntary infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses. Infertility is defined as the inability to conceive or carry a pregnancy to live birth, including infertility resulting from medical treatments like chemotherapy or surgery. The term 'infertility' refers to the inability to conceive or carry a pregnancy to live birth, including iatrogenic infertility from medical treatments. An 'eligible individual' is someone diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician. Married taxpayers must file joint returns for infertility treatment expenses. Adjustments for inflation apply to dollar limitations after December 31, 2012. Married taxpayers must file joint returns for infertility treatment expenses. Dollar limitations are adjusted for inflation after December 31, 2012. The dollar amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(i) is increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $10, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 23A allows for a credit for certain infertility treatments. Various sections of the Internal Revenue Code are amended to include references to section 23A. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011.
